End-of-Day Process

The End-of-Day process may run by site for a reference transaction date, which may be set to the current business day. The timing for running this process may be configurable in the database for each site. The trading day start and end times may be stored in a site table so that at least the end time may be used for the End-of-Day process. In this regard, the trading start/end times may be set in GMT. The process may run twice daily—once for Asia (e.g., Sydney+Hong Kong), and the second time for New York and London, for example. Users need not be required to log out when this process runs. Instead the following warning may be given in the status bar for relevant site(s): “End-of-day” process in progress, which may disappear when the process is completed.

During run time, the End-of-Day process may hold all active prices posted by the selected site (e.g., broker's site) with a transaction date equal to or earlier than the date for which the process is being run. The process may also hold all non-permanent interests without active prices and permanently delete held prices with transaction dates that are earlier than the preceding business day. All held prices from the current business day may be retained in the order book in a held state so that the next morning brokers may see what they were working on the preceding day. The desktops of logged-in users may be refreshed with any updates to the workspace/price sheet configurations. Pop ups may be provided, which include the following message pup up for all logged in users: ‘As part of the EOD process, your desktop will be refreshed with latest workspace/price sheet updates. Please press <ENTER> or press [OK] to continue or [SKIP] to wait until the next business day or your next login.’ The popup may present the user with two response buttons [OK] and [SKIP]. If there is no response from the user within 10 seconds, for example, OK is assumed and the updates are propagated to the client machine. If the user selects [SKIP] the changes are not propagated. The changes may then either go through at the user's next login or the next time the End-Of-Day progress runs.
Interactive Order Management

Selected traders may interactively manage their own orders via the CTS user interference. In this regard, interactive order management may be enabled primarily for the CDS indices. In particular, a setting “The Entity Access Level” may be configured with Entity-Product Line defaults, so that certain types of trading may be permitted by entity name, including, for example, “Voice Only”, “View Only”, “Semi-Interactive”, and “Interactive”. For Voice Only trading, prices and executions related to this entity may not be displayed/published for traders. However, traders may view the details of trades for their own institution in the trade book. For View Only trading, traders may view prices and executions for this entity, but may not interactively maintain their orders or execute trades in this name. Only brokers may have the ability to add, change, remove or execute on the prices. For Semi-Interactive trading, traders may maintain their own orders/prices for interests in this name. However, they may execute trades interactively. For Interactive trading traders may both maintain their own orders/prices for interests in this name, and select bids/offers for execution. In addition to the entity access level, an Interactive Trader role may be created for users, which allows them to interactively manage their orders. Only users with this role may interactively manage orders for entities with either a Semi-Interactive or Interactive Access Level.

Trader functionality may be enabled or disabled in accordance with the trader role and the Entity Access Level. In particular, for entities with a Voice Only access level, the display of interests, prices and trades may be disabled everywhere except in the trade book. Hence, traders may not see any information on these entities within price sheets, the trade and activity logs and the order book. For entities with a View Only access level, interests, prices and trades may be displayed everywhere. The interest, price, update, hit, lift, hold, post, and depth functions may be disabled for traders. For entities with Semi-Interactive or Interactive access levels, interests, prices and trades may be displayed everywhere, and the certain functions, such as, for example, “price”, “bid”, “offer”, “hold”, “update”, “+” and “−”, may be enabled only for Interactive Traders (that is, users with an Interactive Trader role).

In this regard, for non-interactive traders, entities with Semi-Interactive or Interactive access levels may be treated the same as those with a View Only access level. In the price entry dialog, the bid & offer company may default to the trader's own site, and the selection list may be limited to sites for the trader's own institution only. Multi-legged interests may follow the most conservative display route and take the lowest functional common denominator. For example, if in a switch, one entity is Voice Only and the other is Interactive, then the structure may inherit the most restrictive level of access, which in this instance may be Voice Only. No activity should show up in the Activity Log for Voice Only entities, and no activity should show up in the Trade Log for Voice Only Trades. Within the trade book, traders may view the details of all their trades, even those involving Voice Only entities.
Inverted Markets

To prevent the user from entering an inverted market, the system may check whether a price entered or updated by a trader results in an inverted posted market. The check may occur after the trader submits the price but before the price is displayed on screen. In this regard, if a new posted bid is higher than the highest posted offer, then a warning may appear. The warning message may read, for example, “your action will create an inverted market. Do you wish to continue and display an inverted market? [Yes] [No]”, where selecting [yes] may submit or post the price, and selecting [no] ignores the action.

When a price is firmed from the orderbook resulting in an inverted market, orderbook may the price is not finned in the order book and a warning is displayed. If multiple prices are being firmed from the orderbook, those prices that would have generated an inverted market are not firmed in the order book. The other prices may be firmed. A warning may appear once if there are one or more prices that are not re-submitted due to the inverted market conditions being triggered. The warning message for inverted firms from the orderbook may be “some price updates you have submitted would have created an inverted market and have been ignored for your protection. Please check the orderbook for un-submitted prices. [OK]”.

Traders may receive an inverted market warning only when a firm posted price creates an inverted market when compared with the best firm posted price on the opposite side. Brokers may receive an inverted market warning whenever any firm price (posted or unposted) creates an inverted market when compared with the best firm price (posted or unposted) on the opposite side.

In this regard, the timeout value may be specified in terms of minutes and may be added to all bids and offers, and a setting of zero indicates no timeout, that is, an order with a zero timeout value will be a GTC (Good-Till-Canceled) order. Order Management in and with the MyPrices Area

According to an exemplary embodiment, the MyPrices area in pricesheets may allow the viewing, input, editing, holding, and firming of prices without the use of dialog boxes, that is, users may carry out basic order management tasks by typing in key order details directly into the relevant price sheet cells. Brokers and traders may add, update and delete orders directly within the relevant price sheet cells based on the rules. For example, direct cell editing may be enabled only within the MyPrices area, that is, only within these four price sheet columns of My Bid Size, My Bid, My Offer, and My Offer Size. Therefore, direct cell editing may not be permitted in pricesheets that do not include any of the above columns. Since the user may be required to select the trader and site when working in the MyPrices area, direct cell editing may only be enabled for the orders of one trader at a time. Editing may be limited to just the price and size of any order, so that the user may only add basic standard posted orders without special conditions and updates may be limited to just those two fields. When editing an existing order via direct cell input, any data other than the price, size, status (firm/held) or posting status, may remain unaffected by an update—e.g., conditions, hedge flag.

Navigation and parsing rules for in-cell editing may be like those that apply in Excel. For example, the user may use the certain keys to navigate from cell to cell, in which <Enter> may enable vertical movement downwards, <Shift><Enter> may enable vertical movement upwards, <Tab> may enable movement to the next pricesheet, and <Shift><Tab> may enable movement to the previous pricesheet. The four arrow keys may enable movement in the direction of each arrow. If a cursor is at the top, bottom, rightmost or leftmost column in a pricesheet, no further movement in the direction of the arrow may be permitted.

The editable cells may accept only the certain key values to represent the order size and price, including, for example, the numeric characters: 0 through 9, and one period or decimal point. In addition, to allow for the input/maintenance of up-front prices, the My Bid and My Offer cells may accept a ‘+’ sign only when it is preceded by at least one numeric character. Certain special keys may be supported for in-cell editing of price and size data. For example, the space bar to clear the contents of a cell, <Backspace> to make corrections or blank out entered data while the user is in the midst of inputting data in a cell, + to tick up the existing price by one basis point or percent (only when it is used before typing any other valid character into the cell), − to tick down the existing price by one basis point or percent (only when it is used before typing any other valid character into the cell).

Certain special keys may be used for managing order status. For example, the <Delete> key may hold the selected firm order, and the <Insert> key may firm the selected held order. A ‘+’ typed in as the first character within a populated price cell may be interpreted as the increment command and may tick the existing price up. A ‘+’ typed in as the first character within an un-populated price cell may be ignored as an invalid entry. A ‘+’ typed in after a number within a price cell, may be interpreted as part of the price. In this regard, if the interest is an up-front interest, the number preceding the ‘+’ may be taken as the upfront price in %, and any number entered after the ‘+’ may become the running points. If there is no number following the ‘+’, the running points will be set to zero. If the interest is not an up-front interest, the number preceding the ‘+’ may be taken as the price in basis points, and the ‘+’ as well as any characters following the ‘+’ may be ignored. In-cell editing mode may be enabled when the user places his/her focus on an editable cell, and may be invoked as soon as the user types in a valid character as outlined above, provided that there is no related dialog box open at the time. If the user types in an invalid character (alpha or other special characters, including hotkeys) once in-cell editing mode has been invoked, a beep may sound and the invalid character may be ignored. A newly typed-in value may replace the previous content of the cell upon its submission when the user exits the edited cell. When an existing held and/or unposted order is updated via in-cell editing, it may be replaced by a firm posted order. To submit the value entered in a cell, the user may use one of the navigation keys or key combinations above to exit the cell and move to a different cell, or shift the focus elsewhere using a mouse. When editing a cell, if the focus is lost as a result of the user clicking on a button or a menu option, whatever the user has typed into the cell may be submitted as the new value. To cancel editing mode once it has been invoked within a cell, the user may be required to press the <Esc> key to restore the cell's previous contents. Hence, clicking on the <Esc> key may be the only way to invalidate a value input into the cell while the focus is still on the cell. On a new order, if the user types in a price without typing in a size, the size may default to the value selected in the Size dropdown within the MyPrices menubar. Blanking out the price or size may be treated the same as the <Delete> key, that is, it will result in holding the order.

According to an exemplary embodiment, orders that are either created or updated via direct cell input may not be sent to the server until the entry or change is submitted as described above (i.e., after exiting the cell or changing focus). When a value entered into a cell is submitted, the server may validate and process as if the value were entered in the Price dialog and all of the validation rules would apply, including checks for inverted markets, price variation, etc. After the order has been validated, it may be published to all clients and appear in both the MarketPrices and MyPrices (where applicable) areas as a normal order created/updated via the Price dialog. When creating a new order via direct cell input, the order may be created only after a price has been submitted. That is, if the user has entered a size and not yet entered a price, nothing will be sent to the server until a price has been entered. However, a price may be entered without specifying a size, in which case the size may be assumed to be the default value selected in the MyPrices Size dropdown control. When the size of an existing order is updated via direct cell input, the server may process the entry by updating the size on the existing order without changing the position of that order in the queue. When the price of an existing order is updated via direct cell input, the server may process the entry by holding the previous order and replacing it with a new one, so the order's previous queue position may not remain the same. When a change to either the price or size of an existing held order is submitted via direct cell input, the server may process the entry as a firm order. That is, the order may automatically be firmed with the updated details. When a change to either the price or size of an existing unposted order is submitted via direct cell input, the server may process the entry as a posted order. That is, the order may automatically be posted with the updated details.

Accordingly, the user may need to explicitly change the OCO setting when updating an order. Held orders may retain their original OCO setting. Brokers may be able to create and update OCO orders on behalf of a trader with certain limitations. 2-Way Trade Work-Ups

According to an exemplary embodiment, when executing a trade interactively, the initiator as well as the aggressor may be given the option to work-up the size of the trade independently, and then the smaller of the two submitted sizes will be executed, provided that it is equal to or greater than the initial size hit/lifted. In this regard, a new work-up dialog may be presented to both the initiator and aggressor immediately following an interactive execution so the two counterparties may increase the size of the execution subject to certain conditions.

In regards to the trade work-up workflow, when a bid/offer is interactively hit/lifted by a trader, both the aggressor and intiator may each immediately receive a timed pop-up displaying the details of the interest, with an option for each counterparty to independently increase the size. The dialog may count down in seconds, the time available for the counterparties to respond—the remaining seconds may be displayed prominently in large bold white and red font. The number of seconds available may depend on the work-up duration setting for the entity. Each counterparty may set their preferred total size either by typing it in in the field provided or by ticking it up/down to a multiple of the entity's default size, provided that the selected size is not lower than that originally hit/lifted. An increased size or work-up, may be required to be explicitly submitted by clicking on the [Submit] button or by pressing <Enter>. If both counterparties respond by submitting a larger size than that initially executed, then the smaller of the two increased sizes may be traded. If one or both counterparties do not respond within the time frame, then the trade may be created for the originally executed size. For the duration of the work-up, the size and price cell of the bid or offer that was executed may flash with a pale red background currently used in the last trade column.

During the work-up period, the market on the interest may be locked for execution, but not for order entry, that is, users may be allowed to enter and update orders, but not hit or lift orders in that interest. The work-up may terminate either when both counterparties have responded, or when it times out—whichever comes first. The termination of the work-up may finalize the trade, resulting in the removal of the executed bid/offer from the market display, which may unlock the interest for execution. When the trade is finalized, the trade details may be displayed in the trade log, and flashed in the last trade column. Any left over unfilled size from the work-up on either side, may be displayed in broker trade logs via a new message type. For example, if the initiator increased the size from 5MM to 25MM and the aggressor increased it to 15MM, then a total of 15MM may be traded, and brokers may be notified that the initiator desired an additional 10MM. The counterparties may have only one chance to work-up the trade, that is, once the initial work-up times out or is submitted, there may be no further opportunity to work-up that trade.

Only interactive traders may receive the work-up pop-up. If the initiator is not an interactive trader, or is not logged on at that time, then only the aggressing trader may receive the pop-up, and the work-up may terminate either when the aggressor responds or when it times out. The work-up dialog may appear as a modal dialog on top of any other type of screen that might be displayed within the designated display area of the work-up.

If a counterparty to the trade already has one work-up dialog open, then a subsequent work—may not be displayed until the previous one has been dealt with, however the countdown may commence as soon as the original hit/lift is submitted.

Wrapped Price Sheets may prevent the overflow of interest rows below the lower boundary of the price sheet window. Therefore, a wrapped price sheet by definition may not have any vertical scroll bars. A wrapped price sheet may be set up to optionally display a sequence number at the beginning of each interest row, which may be different from the index used for sorting Indexed Price Sheets. The display of a wrapped price sheet may adjust dynamically to fit the current window size based on the certain rules and limitations. For example, if the number of interests is greater than can fit within the vertical boundaries of the current price sheet window, the price sheet may automatically be split up into two or more segments which are placed side by side horizontally until all of the interests are accommodated within the vertical frame. If the space required to accommodate all of the segments of a wrapped price sheet exceeds the current window width, horizontal scroll bars may be provided so the user may view all of the interests. When row numbers are included, their sequencing may span all of the price sheet segments. For example, if each segment contains 20 interest rows, then the first segment may display row numbers 1-20, segment 2 may display row numbers 21-40, and so on. The wrapping configuration may change each time the user resizes the window. For example, when the window is made shorter, then the number of segments may be increased as necessary. Conversely, when the window is made longer, then the number of segments may be reduced. Wrapped price sheets within multi-price sheet workspaces may have a static physical layout because resizing is disabled in such workspaces. Join the Trade Option

According to an exemplary embodiment, when a work-up is in progress, counterparties other than those currently engaged in the work-up may be permitted to “Join the Trade” by submitting a bid or offer at the executed price. In particular, when an execution is in the course of being “worked-up,” with the executed price highlighted and the market on the interest locked for further executions, other users may be permitted to join the trade at the executed price by specifying the desired side (bid/offer) and size. Upon termination of the work-up, the system may automatically match up the “joining” buyers and sellers and generate the necessary executions. In this regard, when an interactive execution is being “worked up,” that is, while the market on the executed interest is locked for execution, and the traded price cell is flashing, a trader or broker may join the trade by submitting a bid/offer at the same price. The join feature may be invoked, for example, by double-clicking on the flashing price cell, by using the Join mouse-menu option (w/focus on the selected price), or by using the J hotkey (w/focus on the selected price). When a user invokes the option, s/he may be presented with a Join dialog/pop-up that will enable the entry of the trader (if the user is a broker), desired side and size. The trader and size may be set to the user's default settings. The Join dialog may display the work-up countdown so that the user knows how much time is available for him/her to join the trade. The user may be required to submit his/her response within the total time allocated for the work-up (e.g., 15 seconds), otherwise the dialog may automatically close when the work-up timer counts down to zero. Accordingly, the window of opportunity provided for joining a trade may be the full duration allocated for the work-up, even if the two respondents engaged in the work-up react within a shorter period. Hence, even if a work-up ends before its allocated duration, the market may continue to remain locked on the interest, and the price cell flashing may continue to enable other interested parties to join the trade. When the work-up ends after responses from both counterparties, any residual amount left over from either counterparty engaged in the work-up, may become the first “joining” order eligible for matching with others who want to join the trade on the opposite side. All bids/offers submitted via this option may be ranked according to their time of submission, with the earliest appearing first on either side. However, a residual size may be ranked from a work-up first on the relevant side. Any previously standing orders at the same price level may not participate in the joining process—in other words, if there is a standing bid or offer at the same price level that was not submitted via the Join option, it may not be included in the queue of orders available for automatic matching. After the termination of the work-up, the system may automatically match up the joining bids and offers based on certain priority rankings, and generate the relevant executions. Depending on the size submitted, a single joining bid may be matched up with one or more joining offer/s, or vice versa. Any unmatched and left over joined orders may be discarded. All counterparties whose joined orders were auto-matched and executed, may receive the appropriate trade ticket pop-ups to inform them of their trade/s.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, how a trade is joined, and how orders are matched within the joined trade, may be prioritized. In particular, certain trader privileges may be grouped into one or more priority “tiers” on each side of the trade, where each tier constitutes a “priority bucket” with certain implications in matching the final buying and selling sizes in the joined trade. Additionally, under certain circumstances brokers may work-up or join a trade on behalf of traders.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, users who wish to join a trade may be prioritized based on the quality (i.e., tightness) of their outstanding bid or offer price with respect to the traded price level in terms of depth or spread. Here, the presence of a quality price in type depth or quality price spread may be defined as a certain multiple of price ticks away from the traded price level. That is, the tight depth or spread range may be calculated from the traded price level. For example, if the traded price level is 12 and the price ticks for the respective interest is 0.5, then the tight depth range is 4×0.5=2 bps: (12−10) for bids or (12−14) for offers. Likewise, if the traded price level is 29 and the price tick for the respective interest is 1, then the tight spread range is 4×1=4 bps: (29−25) for bids or (29−33) for offers. In this regard, the price tick multiple may be a configurable setting, and the calculated depth or spread values may depend on whether a price-quoted interest or spread-quoted interest is involved.

According to another exemplary embodiment of the present invention, counterparties engaged in a trade may join on the opposite side of the trade, regardless of their original positioning with respect to the traded interest. For example, if a party to the trade was originally a seller, such a party may not be restricted from joining the trade as buyer.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, traders may be classified as either “Preferred” or “Standard”, in which the preferred traders receive a higher priority with respect to joining the trade than standard traders. In this regard, the classification of a “Preferred” or “Standard” trading status may be accorded to individuals rather than groups.

To join in the trade, certain pre-conditions may be required. For example, the user may be required to be an interactive trader of credit default swaps (CDS) or a broker acting on behalf of a trader of credit default swap (CDS). To initiate the trade, another user (e.g., another broker or trader) executes a trade that is eligible for joining in a credit default swap (CDS) interest. Here, the trade to be joined may be a single execution (i.e., a single bid is hit or a single offer is lifted) rather than a Deal-by-Volume (DBV) execution (Deal-By-Volume trading explained below). To participate in the trade, the user may elect to automatically join the trade via a live trade dialog, or may notice the traded price cell is flashing within the workspace and manually invoke the “live trades” option. In this regard, the trader may have a standing order at the traded price level on the side being traded.

FIG. 76 is a workflow diagram that presents an exemplary decision process for establishing priority tiers P1 to P6 for matching the orders of participants wishing to join in a single execution trade. Here, each “decision point” is presented in the form of a question, in which the provided outcomes are both exhaustive and mutually exclusive (i.e., there are no other outcomes), and each “branch” of the decision tree describes the eligibility and ranking type for each tier.

The P1 priority tier may be reserved for working-up the original trade of an Initiator or Aggressor. Here, the Initiator is the passive, aggressed party, whose standing order (e.g., bid or offer) was either hit or lifted by the Aggressor, who is considered to be the active, aggressing party.

Traders who join on the same side of the trade with the Initiator are considered to be on the “Initiator's side”, whereas traders who join on the same side of trade as the Aggressor are considered to be on the “Aggressor's side”. For example, if a bid is hit, the traders who post a “buy” order with respect to the traded interest in an attempt to join in the trade are considered to be on the Initiator's side, whereas those traders who post a “sell” order with respect to the traded interest in an attempt to join in the trade are considered to be on the Aggressor's side. Alternatively, if an offer is lifted, the traders who post a “sell” order with respect to the traded interest in an attempt to join in the trade are considered to be on the Initiator's side, whereas the traders who post a “buy” order with respect to the traded interest in an attempt to join in the trade are considered to be on the Aggressor's side.

The P2 priority tier may be reserved for matching the orders of traders whose standing orders for the traded interest match the traded price level when the join process started. Here, traders in the P2 priority tier may be ranked based on the time of posting of orders. It is expected that the P2 priority tier on the Aggressor's side may not have many constituents, if any at all, because none of the orders on the Aggressor's side is expected to be at the traded price level (i.e., the spread is not likely to be zero).

The P3 priority tier may be reserved for counter-parties of the original trade if they elect to switch sides. Accordingly, the P3 priority tier on the Initiator's side is reserved for the Aggressor should the Aggressor elect to switch sides after hitting the Initiator's original bid or lifting the Initiator's original offer, whereas the P3 priority tier on the Aggressor's side is reserved for the Initiator should the Initiator elect to switch sides after making the original bid or offer.

The P4 priority tier may be reserved for matching the orders of certain “Preferred” traders who wish to join the trade but had no posted price for the traded interest when the opportunity to join the trade started, or whose posted price is not at the traded price level.

Traders in the P4 priority tier may be ranked based on how quickly they join the trade (e.g., how quickly they respond to the notification of the opportunity to join in the trade). Accordingly, the orders of traders qualifying at the P4 priority tier level may be handled on a “first-in, first-served” basis.

The P5 priority tier may be reserved for traders who had a quality (i.e., tight) depth or spread price for the traded interest when the opportunity to join in the trade started. In this instance, such traders may be referred to as “Tight Depth Contributors” if they join on the same side as the Initiator, or “Tight Spread Contributors” if they join on the same side as the Aggressor. Here, as stated above, the presence of a quality (tight) depth price may be defined as a certain multiple of price ticks (e.g., four) away from the traded price level. Accordingly, traders who had posted prices within the prescribed range may have priority over other traders with respect to the joined trade.

The traders in P5 priority tier may be ranked based on the proximity of their tight depth or spread prices to the traded level (i.e., the closer the price to the traded level, the higher the ranking within the tier). For owners of prices at the same depth level on the Initiator's side, or for owners of prices at the same spread level on the Aggressor's side, their ranking may be based on the time of posting of their order, by depth, or spread. Prices posted in depth or in spread more than a default number of price ticks (e.g., four) away from the traded price level may be considered non-quality (i.e., too wide), and therefore may not qualify to receive a P5 priority.

The P6 priority tier may be reserved for “Standard” traders who wish to join in the trade but had no posted price for the traded interest when the opportunity to join the trade started, or whose posted price was more than a default number of ticks (e.g., four) in depth or spread away from the traded level. Traders in the P6 priority tier may be ranked based on how quickly they join the trade (e.g., how quickly they respond to the notification of the opportunity to join in the trade). Accordingly, the orders of traders qualifying at the P6 priority tier level may be handled on a “first-in, first-served” basis.

Traders on the Initiator's side who belong to more than one priority tiers may be provided with only the priority associated with their highest tier. Accordingly, participation by a trader in multiple tiers may not be permitted.

Implementation of the priority tiers may take into account certain “Privilege Diffusion” rules, in which the tier participants lend privileges to their colleagues within the same tier. That is, certain privileges of a user may “diffuse” to certain other users. Here, for example, certain colleagues and brokers may act as proxies with the same privileges to join a trade as the original price owners. Thus, the privilege diffusion rules may act as a protection mechanism for traders who are temporarily not in direct contact with their screens because they may be away from their desk, have a local desktop problem or are otherwise too busy. In this regard, the preferred status may not apply to price diffusion rules.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, a trader with an active price on an interest that is currently worked up may “lend” his privileges and associated priorities to colleagues from the same site for participation on the same side of the traded interest. For example, a trader from Goldman NY with an existing bid (but no offer) on a traded interest may “lend” his privileges to other traders from Goldman NY who wish to join the trade as buyers. By contrast, the traders from Goldman NY may not receive special privileges from the NY trader on the selling side for the same interest since the attempted participation is not on the same side of the traded interest. Additionally, traders from Goldman London may not receive special privileges from the NY traders since they do not trade from the same site (i.e., NY).

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, the privileges of a screen supporter derived from a standing order may be “lent” to his colleagues only for participation on the traded interest but not others interests. For example, if a trader from SocGen NYK has a standing price on BRITEL 5y, the trader may lend his privileges to his colleagues only for BRITEL 5y JTT participation. Moreover, the privileges of a screen supporter derived from a standing order may be “lent” to colleagues from the same site only for participation on the same side of the trade (i.e., not on the opposite side of the trade). For example, if a trader from Lehman Ldn has a standing offer, he may lend his privileges to his colleagues only for Lehman Ldn sellers (but not buyers) on that interest.

According to an exemplary embodiment, multiple traders from the same institution may wish to trade on the same side of the executed interest. In this instance, if multiple traders from the same institution occupy more than one tier level (for example, by posting prices at traded levels and in depth), all such traders may be treated as though they belong to only the highest ranked tier (i.e., participation in multiple tiers by a single trader may not be permitted).

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, running points (i.e., interest for upfront premium payments) may be ignored when calculating the depth quality for an interest trading with upfront payments. In the case of switches, the depth and spread quality for the traded interest may be calculated for the greater of the 2 legs' price ticks. As stated earlier, the presence of a quality depth price may be defined as a certain multiple of price ticks (e.g., four) away from the traded price level. In this regard, such a multiple may be referred to as the “Price Tick Multiple”, and may be a configurable field.

A trader's status of “Preferred” or “Standard” may be set, for example, via the Data Buffet (DB), or by any other suitable configurable arrangement.

In this regard, the desk head brokers may convey the information to system support personnel, who may update the Data Buffet (DB) settings periodically. Also, standing orders that are not at the traded level may not be deleted after the trade was joined even if the owners of the orders were matched during the joined trade. Held, subjected or unposted standing orders may not participate in the joined trade.

Automatically Joining the Trade

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, traders having standing orders on the same side of a trade at the traded price level may be automatically joined in the trade. Additionally, once the user is automatically joined in the trade, the user may have the option to change the size of the order, change sides or cancel the join request.

FIG. 89 shows an exemplary workflow diagram that presents an exemplary decision process for automatically joining a trade. As shown in FIG. 89, standing orders in depth at the traded price level on the same side of the trade may be automatically joined for the amount of the original standing order. Here, both broker-entered orders and trader-entered orders may be automatically joined. In this regard, orders that are automatically joined may be handled at the P2 priority tier level since such an order is a standing order at the traded price level.

A live trade dialog may be provided, which informs the user that his standing order has been automatically joined in the trade and also provides the user with the ability to update the joined order amount and the ability to switch sides (from buy to sell or vice-versa). Users may also have the ability to withdraw from an automatically joined trade via a cancel button.

A standing order that is automatically joined may remain on the screen during the regular join process, and once the allocated time period for joining the trade expires, the automatically joined order may be matched if a buyer or seller is available. Automatically joined standing orders that are matched may be held since such orders are considered as traded. However, if automatically joined standing orders are not matched they may remain in the market and may retain their priority rank or move up in rank if higher ranking standing orders have been traded or held. Unposted or subject orders may not be eligible for auto-joining. Likewise, orders with sizes less than the minimum order size, or sizes that are not a multiple of the default lot size for the interest, may also not be eligible for auto-joining.

For example, if the user is automatically joined on the “buy” side of a trade, a live trade dialog may be presented to the user, which displays the message: “Automatically joined in to buy <size>MM”, as shown, for example, in the exemplary live dialog 9000a of FIG. 90A. In particular, as shown in the exemplary live dialog 9000a of FIG. 90A, a “Buy <size> More” button 9001a is provided to purchase an amount in addition to the amount automatically joined to buy, a “Sell <size>” button 9002a is provided to sell a certain amount rather than purchase the amount automatically joined to buy, and a “Cancel” button 9003a is provided to cancel the automatically joined trade. Considering the exemplary live trade dialog 9000a of FIG. 90A, for example, by clicking the “Buy <size> More” button 9001 the trader issues a request to buy the indicated amount in addition to the amount already secured by the automatically joined trade. That is, if the amount for the automatically joined trade is originally 5MM, for example, then by clicking the “Buy 5 More” button the trader issues a request to buy 5MM more units in addition to the 5MM already secured by the automatically joined trade for an overall total of 10MM units. In this regard, assuming the trader has opted to buy the 5MM more units, the system may respond with an indication that the trader is automatically joined in the trade for 5MM but that the system is “Trying to buy 10MM”, as shown, for example, in the exemplary live dialog 9000c of FIG. 90C. Thereafter, if the request is successful, then the system may provide an indication in the join status field 9004d stating that the order has been “Filled!”, as shown, for example, in the exemplary live dialog 9000d of FIG. 90D. By contrast, should the trader decide to cancel the automatically joined trade by selecting the “Cancel” or “Cancel Order” button 9003a/b/c, may provide an indication in the join status field 9004e stating that the system is now “Cancelling [the] request”, as shown, for example, in the exemplary live trade dialog 9000e of FIG. 90E.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, a trader may receive a live trade dialog regarding an automatically joined trade only if the system is properly configured to provide this dialog to the trader. For example, the system may require that the trader have a “Popup Live Trades” option selected in the workspace preference window in order to receive such dialogs. In this regard, if the system is not configured to provide these dialogs (e.g., the “Popup Live Trades” option is not enabled for this trader), the trader may not receive such dialogs but may be automatically joined in the trade nonetheless.

If the trader's order is filled as part of an automatically joined trade, the trader may receive an indication that the order was filled along with an option to access the trade ticket via the live trade dialog. In the case of a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution, any orders in depth that were not part of the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution but are eligible for auto-join, may be automatically joined. Orders that were standing at the time of the original trade on the same side of the trade at the traded price level may be automatically joined at the P2 priority tier level. Prior to completion of the automatically joined trade, the trader may adjust the size of his order and/or switch to the opposite side of the trade as desired and submit his request, or withdraw from the trade.

The owner of each standing order may be presented with a live trade dialog with an indication as to which side of the joined trade the trader's order is to be joined with. A buy or sell button may be provided, which displays “Buy <size> More” or “Sell <size> More” depending on the side of the automatically joined trade. The buy or sell button for the opposite side may display “Buy <size>” or “Sell <size>”. If the user buys or sells more, the amount will be in addition to the joined amount, and the join status may display “Trying to Buy/Sell <auto-joined amount>+<amount of the join> . . . ” Accordingly, if trader is automatically joined to buy 5MM and he buys 10MM more, the join status field may display, for example: “Trying to buy 15MM . . . ” In this regard, if the trader requests to adjust the size of his order with respect to the automatically joined trade, he maintains his original ranking with respect to others joined in the trade.

Unposted prices, subject prices, prices with sizes that are less then the minimum size of the interest, and prices with sizes that are not a multiple of the default lot size of the entity, may be excluded from the automatically joined trade.

If the trader switches the side of his automatically joined request, he may be placed into his respective tier on the offer side of the trade. For example, if a trader with a standing bid and an offer is automatically joined on the bid side, or if the trader switches side on the automatically joined trade, his join on the sell will go into the P4 priority tier if the trader is a preferred trader, or the P5 priority tier if the trader has a standing order on the opposite side, which is considered to be within the tight spread range, or the P6 priority tier if the trader does not have a standing order on the opposite side or if the trader has a standing order on the opposite side that is not within the tight spread range.

If the trader switches sides on his automatically joined request, his related standing order may be held. For example, if a trader with a bid of 5M switches to sell after the bid is automatically joined, the bid may be held regardless of whether or not the trader's request to join is matched. Here, by switching sides the trader is declaring a change in direction, and therefore it is assumed that his original order is no longer valid.

If the trader withdraws his automatically joined request, the trader's related standing order may be held. However, if the trader makes no changes during the allocated time to work-up or join in the trade, the trader's request may be submitted for the original order side and size when the time expires, and the trader may maintain his original ranking.

During the join process, if the standing order is held by a “One-Cancels-Other” (OCO) action, the timer or manual “Hold” action (e.g., “Hold” or “Hold All”) then the standing order may be held in the market but the join request is not withdrawn. If the standing order is held but the join request is not withdrawn, the trader may lose their priority ranking and be relegated to either the P4 priority tier, if the trader is a preferred trader, or the P6 priority tier, if the trader is a standard trader. The only time an automatically joined trade may be withdrawn is when the trader, or the broker on the trader's behalf, manually cancels the automatically joined trade via the live trade dialog.

At the end of the allocated time to work-up or join the trade, all related standing orders that were matched via the join process may be deemed to have been filled, and consequently may be held in the market even when an automatically joined trade is only partially filled. Automatically joined trades that are matched may be un-posted, depending upon the configuarion of the system. If a standing order is matched or held, a “Held Price” message may be provided to all joined traders from other institutions in a price log. Traders from the automatically joined trader's institution may see the un-posted trade message in the trade log. Brokers may see the un-posted trade message in the trade log if their request to join the trade is matched.

At the end of the allocated time to work-up or join the trade, all related standing orders on the same side of an automatically joined trade that were unmatched via the join process, may remain standing in their original state as long as the trader did not switch sides. The standing orders may not reflect size changes made via the live trade dialog on the related automatically joined request. An indication regarding the automatically joined trade may be provided in the broker's trade log as follows:

Upon completion of an automatically joined trade, the standing orders of those who did not join the trade, or those who were automatically joined but did not subsequently trade as part of the automatically joined process, may be preserved. Likewise, standing orders with prices not at the traded price level of the automatically joined trade may be preserved once the automatically joined trade is completed even if the owners of the orders were matched during the automatically joined trade.
Held, subjected or un-posted standing orders may not participate in the automatically joined trade.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, trades involving bonds, such as, for example, investment grade bonds (IGBs), may be joined. In particular, certain traders and/or brokers acting on behalf of bond traders may have the ability to work-up or join a trade. Here, such brokers may initiate trades not only on behalf of the traders, but also on behalf of their own site account. In this regard, the brokers may be Aggressors, but not Initiators.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, priority tier levels may be maintained and the workflows preserved in a manner similar to that for credit default swaps (CDS). Certain bond traders may have the option to receive a live trade popup dialog automatically. The eligibility of a trader to join a bond trade may be configured via a “WorkUp Time” checkbox, in a manner similar to credit default swaps (CDS). The allocated time to work-up or join in a trade for bonds may be restricted to a certain time period (e.g., 30 seconds). The default trading size for joining a trade for bonds may be 1 M, and thereafter configurable, for example, in increments of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10, 15 or 20 M.

Deal-By-Volume Trading

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, traders of certain interests, including credit default swaps (CDS), may “Deal-By-Volume”, that is, such traders may hit or lift multiple standing bids/offers all at once simultaneously. In particular, the traders may simultaneously trade against two or more standing orders, at one or more price levels, based on certain rules and conditions described below.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, credit default swap (CDS) interests may be enabled for a “Deal-By-Volume” (DBV) trade at the best price level. In addition, an entity-level setting may indicate whether or not traders may be permitted to “Deal By Volume” (DBV) at multiple price levels. Depending on this entity setting, traders may simultaneously hit or lift multiple bids/offers at either the best price level only, or at multiple price levels within the depth.

An exemplary hit or lift dialog for traders may provide a more user-friendly interface for single-order executions, as well as multi-execution Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trades. Here, the desired volume may be made by combining orders at multiple price levels, in which the system computes and displays the execution price as a Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) of the selected orders. In this regard, when a “Deal-By-Volume” (DBV) trade is submitted, the system may generate an execution for each unique combination of buyer, price, and seller.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, a default setting entitled “Multi-Price Deal-By-Volume” (MP-DBV) at the entity level for the credit default swap (CDS) product line may be used to indicate whether or not traders may simultaneously execute orders at multiple price levels for credit default swap (CDS) interests against each entity. The Multi-Price Deal-By-Volume (MP-DBV) setting may appear below the “Hold on Execution” setting on the credit default swap (CDS) entity defaults page. In this regard, the Multi-Price Deal-By-Volume (MP-DBV) setting may be a Boolean value (e.g., Yes/No), and may be administered via a checkbox, which defaults to unchecked (e.g., No) for new entities, so a data administrator may need to explicitly check this setting when desired.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, when the Multi-Price Deal-By-Volume (MP-DBV) setting is unchecked, traders may simultaneously hit or lift multiple bids/offers provided that the traders all have a price that matches the best available price. When Multi-Price Deal-By-Volume (MP-DBV) is checked, traders may simultaneously hit or lift multiple bids/offers, at multiple price levels.

When a trader hits a bid or lifts an offer, if the trader is positioned on a non-executable bid, or offer, the hit or lift may be assumed to be against the first executable bid or offer in the depth. A trader hit/lift dialog may open up with the bid or offer that was hit or lifted as well as all executable bids or offers above it in the depth selected for trading. The total size of the trade may be set to the sum of the full sizes of the orders selected for execution.

The Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) (execution price) may be set to the calculated weighted average price of the orders selected for execution. The depth table may display all the prices, sizes and eligibility of all executable orders on the selected side for the interest per the rules (discussed below). At this point, if the trader just submits the trade without making any changes, and the selected orders are still available for execution, the related execution records may be generated. The trader may change the desired size either by checking or unchecking one or more of the orders eligible for Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution in the depth table. Each time the trade size is altered, the system may dynamically recalculate the Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) for execution as more fully described below. The trader may then submit the trade either by pressing “<Enter>”, or the “Hit/Lift” button. At this point, if the selected prices and sizes are still available, the trade may be processed, the related execution record/s may be generated, and the exemplary dialog box 10,000 may be closed.

When a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) is successfully sent and processed, certain related events may occur. For example, the system may generate an execution record for each unique combination of price, buyer and seller, the executed prices may be removed from the market, and the unfilled portion of the requested size from a non-AON Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade may be ignored. Additionally, a trade log may be provided, which displays a message for each related execution, and the users who have elected to be alerted may receive the related trade alert pop-ups.

For any given interest, certain rules may determine whether or not an order is executable by the aggressor, and whether or not the order is eligible for Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution. In particular, all posted firm orders in the depth that do not belong to the aggressor's institution may be deemed to be executable by him, and the order's eligibility for inclusion in a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade may depend on the definition of the reference entity on the selected interest. For example, if the entity on the selected interest is Multi-Price Deal-By-Volume (MP-DBV)-enabled, then all orders may be eligible for inclusion in a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution. By contrast, if the entity on the selected interest is not enabled for Multi-Price Deal-By-Volume (MP-DBV), then all orders at the best price level only may be eligible for inclusion in the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade.

In the exemplary trader hit/lift dialog 10,000, the system may determine the Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) according to certain rules. For example, when the trade is executed against a single order, the Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) may be set to the price of that order. When a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade is executed against more than one order at the same price level, the Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) may be set to the price of the first eligible order.

When a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade involves two or more orders at two or more price levels, the Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) may be calculated according to certain rules. For example, the cost attributable to each order involved in the trade may be computed by multiplying the size of the order by the price of the order. For up-front interests, the cost calculation may performed, only by multiplying the size of each order by the up-front portion of the price. In this regard, it is assumed that the running points are constant, and therefore there may be no need to include the running points in the calculation of the average price. The individual costs of the orders involved in the trade may then be added together to compute the total trade cost. The total trade cost may then be divided by the total size to compute the Volume-Weighted Average Price, (i.e., the average execution price). For up-front interests, the Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) may be set to the calculated average price (of the up-front portions only), plus the running points of the best bid/offer. If the total size is adjusted up or down by selecting or deselecting one or more eligible orders, the Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) may be dynamically re-calculated and updated within the dialog.

If the underlying market conditions change between the time a trader first opens the hit/lift dialog 10,000 and the subsequent submission of his Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request, the system may handle the situation according to certain rules. For example, on an “All or None” (AON) trade, the system may attempt to fill the exact requested size from the updated depth at an equivalent or better Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) without generating any partial executions against standing orders. If this is not possible, the trade may be rejected. On a non-AON trade, by contrast, the system may attempt to fill the requested size either partially, or fully, from the updated depth at an equivalent or better Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) without generating partial executions against the standing order(s). If even a partial execution is not possible, the trade may be rejected. On interests against entities that are not enabled for Multi-Price Deal-By-Volume (MPDBV) trades, the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request may be rejected if it cannot be performed at a single price level that is equal to or better than the requested Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP).

If a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade is rejected as a result of changes in the underlying market, the exemplary hit/lift dialog 10,000 may remain open, and may be updated with certain information. For example, the status box 10,003 may display the following message: “Underlying market changed. Your execution was not successful. Please try again”. Additionally, the depth table may be refreshed with the current market orders, the first eligible order may be auto-selected for execution, the Total Size and Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) fields may be set to display the size and price of the first eligible order, and The “All or None” (AON) field may be unchecked.

Several “Concurrent Event” (CE) scenarios may affect how the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) feature operates. For example, according to one exemplary concurrent event, an order that is selected for an “All or None” (AON) Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade may be held. Here, if the aggressor subsequently submits a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request, the system may then attempt to fill the entire requested size from the remaining depth at an equivalent or better Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) without generating partial executions against the standing order(s). If the system succeeds in filling the trade from the remaining depth the trade request may be processed. Otherwise, if the system fails to satisfy the trade request, the trade may be rejected.

In another exemplary concurrent event, an order that is selected for a non-AON Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade may be held. Here, if the aggressor subsequently submits the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request, the system may then attempt to fill all or part of the requested size from the remaining depth at an equivalent or better Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) without generating any partial executions against standing orders. If the system succeeds in filling all or some of the requested trade size from the remaining depth, the trade request may be processed. Otherwise, if the system fails to fill part or all of the requested trade size at a Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) equal to or better than that requested, the trade may be rejected.

In another exemplary concurrent event, a new order may be submitted on the same side with a better price than one or more of the orders selected for an “All or None” (AON) Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade. Here, if the aggressor subsequently submits the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request and if the new order is executable by the aggressor and is eligible for Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution, then the system may perform certain actions. For example, the system may deselect all previously selected orders at the “worse” price levels in the depth queue and include the new order in the execution, provided that the overall order size when combined with the sizes of all previously selected orders above the new order in the depth queue does not exceed the total requested size. The system may also make up any remaining size deficit by selecting one or more orders at worse price levels to exactly match the total requested size. If the system succeeds in coming up with an order combination including the new order that equals the total size requested, then the trade may be processed at a better than requested Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP). However, if the system fails to satisfy the trade request, the trade may be rejected.

In another exemplary concurrent event, a new order may be submitted on the same side with a better price than one or more of the orders selected for a non-AON Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade. Here, if the aggressor subsequently submits the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request, and if the new order is executable by the aggressor and is eligible for Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution, then the system may perform certain actions. For example, the system may deselect all previously selected orders at worse price levels in the depth queue and include the new order in the execution, provided that the overall order size when combined with the sizes of all previously selected orders above the new order in the depth queue does not exceed the total requested size. The system may also make up any remaining size deficit by selecting one or more orders at “worse” price levels without exceeding the total requested size. If the system succeeds in coming up with an order combination including the new order that is equal to or less than the total size requested, then the trade may be processed at a better than requested Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP). However, if the system fails to fill part or all of the requested trade size at a Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) equal to or better than that requested, the trade may be rejected.

In another exemplary concurrent event, an order selected for inclusion in an “All or None” (AON) Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade may be executed by another trader. Here, if the aggressor subsequently submits the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request, the system may attempt to fill the entire requested size from the remaining depth at an equivalent or better Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) without generating partial executions against the standing order(s). If the system succeeds in filling the trade from the remaining depth, the trade request may be processed. Otherwise, if the system fails to satisfy the trade request, the trade may be rejected.

In another exemplary concurrent event, an order selected for inclusion in a non-AON Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade may be executed by another trader. Here, if the aggressor submits the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request, the system may attempt to fill all or part of the requested size from the remaining depth at an equivalent or better Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) without generating partial executions against the standing order(s). If the system succeeds in filling all or some of the requested trade size from the remaining depth, the trade request may be processed. Otherwise, if the system fails to fill part or all of the requested trade size at a Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) equal to or better than that requested, the trade may be rejected.

In another exemplary concurrent event, the size is decremented on an order that is selected for inclusion in a “All or None” (AON) Deal-By-Volume (DBV). Here, if the aggressor submits the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request, the system may attempt to fill the exact requested size from the remaining depth at an equivalent or better Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) without generating partial executions against the standing order(s). If the system succeeds in filling the trade from the remaining depth, the trade request may be processed. Otherwise, if the system fails to satisfy the trade request, the trade may be rejected.

In another exemplary concurrent event the size may be decremented on an order that is selected for inclusion in an “All or None” (AON) Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade. Here, if the aggressor submits the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request, the system may attempt to fill all or part of the requested size from the remaining depth at an equivalent or better Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) without generating partial executions against the standing order(s). If the system succeeds in filling all or some of the requested trade size from the remaining depth, the trade request may be processed. Otherwise, if the system fails to fill part or all of the requested trade size at a Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) equal to or better than that requested, the trade may be rejected.

In another concurrent event, the size may be incremented on an order that is selected for inclusion in an “All or None” (AON) Deal-By-Volume (DBV). Here, if the aggressor submits the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request, and if the updated order is the last one originally selected, the trade may fail because it may not be possible to match the requested size and Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) exactly, and so the trade may be rejected. If the updated order is not the last one, the system may drop one or more orders starting with the bottom of the selected order queue in an attempt to come up with a combination that matches the requested size exactly. If the system succeeds in coming up with an order combination including the updated order that equals the total size requested, then the trade may be processed at a better than requested Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP). Otherwise, if the system fails to satisfy the trade request, the trade may be rejected.

In another exemplary concurrent event, the size may be incremented on an order that is selected for inclusion in a non-AON Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade. Here if, the aggressor submits the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request, the system may drop one or more orders starting with the bottom of the selected order queue in an attempt to come up with full or partial execution of the requested trade size. If the system succeeds in coming up with an order combination including the updated order that is equal to or less than the total size requested then the trade may be processed at a better than requested Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP). Otherwise, if the system fails to satisfy the trade request, the trade may be rejected.

FIGS. 101A and 101B show an exemplary Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade scenario for a non-MPDBV-enabled entity. Here, it is assumed that the Multi-Price Deal-By-Volume (MPDBV) setting for General Motors Corp. is set to ‘No’, and the current market on a GM 5y interest is as shown in FIG. 101A. If trader CITI7 hits the best bid of 45 in 5M from GOSA1 then a Hit/Lift dialog may be provided, which displays a Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) of 45, a total (trade) size of 5, and a depth table as the one displayed in FIG. 101B. Since CITI7 cannot select any other bids to hit, CITI7 submits the trade for 45 in 5M. GOSA1 and CITI7 receive a work-up dialog. Assuming JPM5 has elected to receive explicit invitation to join this type of trade, JPM5 receives a live trade dialog to which GOSA1 decides to work up the trade by indicating that he wants to buy 10M more. CITI7 does not want to work up and dismisses the work-up dialog. Thus, the trade between GOSA1 and CITI7 is finalized—CITI7 sells 5M to GOSA1, and PM5 joins in to sell 5M. When the work-up timer expires, GOSA1's residual size from the work-up on the buy side is matched up with JPM5's join on the sell side for an additional trade of 5M—i.e, GOSA1 buys an additional 5M from JPM5. Thereafter, the two trades may be published in the Trade Log, and users who have elected to be alerted about trades for the related workspace/s may receive a trade alert popup.

FIGS. 102A to 102E show an exemplary Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade scenario at a single price level. Here, assuming the Multi-Price Deal-By-Volume (MPDBV) setting is enabled for the Ford Motor Company, the current market on a Ford 5y interest is shown in FIG. 102A. If trader CITI7 hits the best bid of 120 in 5M then a Hit/Lift dialog may be provided, which displays a Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) of 120, a size of 5, and a depth table as displayed in FIG. 102B. CITI7 then checks the second bid to increment the total size up to 10 so now the depth table is as displayed in FIG. 102C. Here, the Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) remains unchanged at 120. Now CITI7 checks the third bid as well to increment the total size to 15 so now the depth table is as displayed in FIG. 102D. Here, the Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) is re-calculated and updated to 115. Since CITI7 does not want to sell below 120, CITI7 unchecks the worst bid to decrease size back down to 10M so now the depth table is as displayed in FIG. 102E. Here, the Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) is re-calculated and updated to 120. CITI7 likes the details and submits the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) request by clicking on the “Hit” button. No traders receive either the work-up or the join dialog. Thereafter, the two trades are finished and may be published in the trade log as CITI7 buys 5M @ 120 from GOSA1 and CITI7 buys 5M @ 120 from JPM5″. A user who has elected to be alerted about trades for the related workspaces may receive a trade alert popup.

FIGS. 103A to 103D show an exemplary Deal-By-Volume (DBV) scenario at multiple price levels. Here, assuming the Multi-Price Deal-By-Volume (MPDBV) setting has been enabled for the Ford Motor Company, and the current market on a Ford 5y interest is as shown in FIG. 103A. If trader CITI7 hits the best bid of 120 in 5M, a Hit dialog may be provided, which displays a Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) of 120, a size of 5, and a depth table is displayed as in FIG. 103B. CITI7 now checks the second bid to increment the total size up to 10 so that the depth table is displayed as in FIG. 103C. The Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) remains unchanged at 120. Now CITI7 checks the third bid as well to increment the total size to 15 so the depth table is as displayed in FIG. 103D. The Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) is then re-calculated and updated to 115. CITI7 likes the details and submits the Deal By Volume (DBV) request by clicking on the “Hit” button. No traders receive either the work-up or the join dialog. Three trades are now finished and may be published in the trade log as “CITI7 buys 5M @120 from GOSA1. CITI7 buys 5M @120 from JPM5. CITI7 buys 5M @105 from GOSA12”. Users who have elected to be alerted about trades for the related workspaces may receive a trade alert popup.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, a trade may be joined after a Deal-by-Volume execution at single price level. In particular, interactive traders of credit default swaps (CDS) may join a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade executed at single price levels. By contrast, Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trades executed at multiple price levels may be exempted. Here, single executions may be viewed as examples of Deal-By-Volume (DBV) executions with only one Initiator, joining the trade after a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution may follow similar logic flow and matching priorities as joining a trade for single executions. Participants in a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution may have the opportunity to join a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution trade at the traded price level.

FIG. 104 is a workflow diagram that presents an exemplary decision process for establishing priority tiers P1 to P6 for matching bids/offers of traders wishing to join in a trade after a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution. Here, each “decision point” is presented in the form of a question, in which the outcomes are exhaustive and mutually exclusive (i.e. there are no other outcomes), and each “branch” of the decision tree describes the eligibility and ranking type for each tier.

As a pre-condition to joining the trade after a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution, the user may be required to be an interactive credit default swap (CDS) trader. Here, the Aggressor (e.g., trader, or broker acting on behalf of a trader) may execute the Deal-by-Volume trade in a credit default swap (CDS) interest on an entity set for MP-DBV. The tiers and their associated matching priorities (P1 to P6) may be similar or identical as those provided for a single execution. However, for a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) executed trade, there may be multiple Initiators joined in trade, whose prices either were hit or lifted by the Aggressor. Accordingly, the multiple Initiators in a joined trade after Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution may be ranked in the P1 priority tier on the Initiator side and/or the P3 priority tier on the Aggressor side. The ranking may be based on the time of posting the standing order. Accordingly, the earlier the price was posted, the higher the ranking. In this regard, the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution may be handled on an “All or None” (AON) or a non-AON basis. The Deal-by-Volume (DBV) trade may be executed at a single price level on the Initiator side (i.e., multiple price levels may not be permitted).

To receive notification about an opportunity to join a trade after a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution, the user may either elect to automatically receive live trade dialogs in the related workspace, or the user may notice the traded price cell flashing within the workspace and manually invoke the live trades dialog. The window of opportunity to join in the trade may be restricted to within a certain period of time (e.g., 30 seconds).

FIG. 105 shows in table form exemplary scenarios for each priority tier P1 to P6 in which an invitation to work-up or join a trade after a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution is possible and how it may occur. In particular, as indicated in FIG. 105, either a buyer or seller who qualifies to trade at the P1 or P3 priority tier levels may be invited to work-up the trade as a buyer or seller with the option to buy more or sell more in size increments of 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, or 40 units. Likewise, a buyer or seller who qualifies to trade at the P2, P4, P5 and P6 priority tier levels may be invited to join the trade as a buyer or seller with the option to buy or sell in size increments of 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35 or 40 units.

Upon expiration of the allocated time to work-up or join the trade, a live trade dialog may be presented to the trader(s) with information regarding whether any request to work-up or join the trade was successful or not. Join the Trade After DBV for Bonds

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, trades involving bonds, such as, for example, investment grade bonds (IGBs), may be joined after a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution. In particular, traders of bonds and certain brokers of bonds may work-up or join a trade after a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution at single price levels. In this regard, Deal-By-Volume (DBV) executions at multiple price levels may not be permitted.

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, certain priority tier levels may be disabled. For example, he priority tier level P4, which is reserved for tight depth contributors, may be disabled by setting the “Price Tick Multiple” to 0 for bonds.

As a pre-condition to work-up or join a trade for bonds after a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution, the user may be required to be an interactive trader of bonds or a broker acting on behalf of a trader of bonds. To initiate the trade an aggressor (e.g., trader, or broker acting on behalf of a trader or on his own behalf) may execute a Deal-by-Volume bond trade. Here, the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade request may be handled on a “All or None” (AON) or a non-AON basis. In this regard, the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) trade may be executed at a single price level on the Initiator side (i.e., multiple price levels may not be permitted). To access the trade, the user may either elect to be automatically joined in the trade in the related workspace, or the user may notice that the traded price cell is flashing within the workspace and manually invoke a live trade dialog. The window of opportunity to join in the trade may be restricted to a certain time period (e.g., 30 seconds).

According to an exemplary embodiment of the present invention, the tiers and their associated matching priorities (P1 to P6) may be the same or similar as for the single execution joint trades for bonds. Since this a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) situation, there may be multiple Initiators whose prices were either hit or lifted by the Aggressor (e.g., trader or broker acting on behalf of the trader). The multiple Initiators joined in the trade after the Deal-By-Volume (DBV) execution may be ranked in the P1 priority tier on the Initiator's side of the trade or the P3 priority tier on the Aggressor's side of the trade. The ranking may be based on the time of posting the standing order, that is, the earlier the price was posted, the higher the ranking.

FIG. 108 shows in table form exemplary scenarios for each priority tier P1 to P6 in which an invitation to work-up or join a trade for bonds after a Deal-By-Volume (DBV) is possible and how it may occur. In particular, as indicated in FIG. 108, either a buyer or seller who qualifies to trade at the P1 or P3 priority tier levels may be invited to work-up the trade as a buyer or seller with the option to buy more or sell more in size increments of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10, 15 or 20 units. Likewise, a buyer or seller who qualifies to trade at the P2, P5 and P6 priority tier levels may be invited to join the trade as a buyer or seller with the option to buy or sell in size increments of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10, 15 or 20 units.
